page.title: 02Ecology: Mid Cynon Valley
page.content: Building is restricted to the lower valley sides, leaving the upper stretches of the valley covered in moorland and heath (Calluna, Mollinia, Nardus). Soils such as (podzols) are common. Much of the original deciduous woodland has been removed either for use as fuel or pit props, and remnants of this ecosystem are scattered. The Forestry Commission has planted trees in several areas. Some natural marshland can be found on the flood-plain of the Cynon. The climate and weather are typical for this part of Wales. Rainfall is orographic and frequently associated with Tropical Maritime air masses, rainfall is heaviest in autumn and winter. April is usually the driest month. Pollution of the valley from the emissions of the Phurnacite affect soils and plants.
